The 'Rhine' (; ; ; ) is a European river that runs from the Swiss canton of
Grisons in the southeastern Swiss Alps through Germany and eventually flows into
the North Sea coast in the Netherlands and is the twelfth longest river in
Europe, at about , with
an average discharge of more than .

The Rhine and the Danube formed most of the northern inland frontier of the
Roman Empire and, since those days, the Rhine has been a vital and navigable
waterway carrying trade and goods deep inland. It has also served as a defensive
feature and has been the basis for regional and international borders. The many
castles and prehistoric fortifications along the Rhine testify to its importance
as a waterway. River traffic could be stopped at these locations, usually for
the purpose of collecting tolls, by the state that controlled that portion of
the river.
